WHAT.TITLE: What?
WHAT.BODY:
This tool introduces machine learning by providing hands-on experiences for training machine learning systems and building things with them.

It provides an easy-to-use guided environment for training machine learning models for classifying text, numbers or recognising images.

This builds on existing efforts to introduce and teach coding to children, by adding these models to Scratch (a widely used educational coding platform), allowing children to create projects and build games with the machine learning models that they've trained.

WHY.TITLE: Why?
WHY.BODY:
Machine learning is all around us. We all use machine learning systems every day - such as spam filters, recommendation engines, language translation services, chatbots and digital assistants, search engines, and fraud detection systems.

It will soon be normal for machine learning systems to drive our cars, and help doctors to diagnose and treat our illnesses.

It's important that kids are aware of how our world works. The best way to understand the capabilities and implications is to be able to build with this technology for themselves.

To learn more, read: 'Introducing Machine Learning to kids'

TECH.TITLE: Tech
TECH.BODY:
The tool is entirely web-based and requires no installs or complicated setup to be able to use.

It was designed for use in the classroom by schools and volunteer-run coding groups for children,and provides an admin page for teachers or group leaders to be able to manage and administer access for their students.

It is being built by Dale Lane using APIs from IBM Watson Developer Cloud.

WELCOME.TITLE: Teach a computer to play a game
WELCOME.STEP_1_TEXT: Collect examples of things you want to be able to recognise
WELCOME.STEP_2_TEXT: Use the examples to train a computer to be able to recognise them
WELCOME.STEP_3_TEXT: Make a game in Scratch that uses the computer's ability to recognise them

SCRATCH.TITLE: Scratch issues
SCRATCH.Q1: I don't know how to get Scratch working
SCRATCH.Q1-A-1: Machine Learning for Kids uses Scratch 2. Scratch needs Adobe Flash to work, so you need to be using an operating system and a web browser that can work with Flash (so that means no iPads for now, sorry).
SCRATCH.Q1-A-2: If you're not sure about how to enable Flash, you can download a document with some tips for getting Scratch working.
SCRATCH.Q2: The "Load Project" and "Save Project" menus in Scratch don't work
SCRATCH.Q2-A-1: If you're using Safari on macOS and the Scratch menus "File -> Load Project" and "File -> Save Project" menus aren't working, it might be that you're running in Safe Mode.
SCRATCH.Q2-A-2: Follow the instructions here for how to check and fix this.
SCRATCH.Q3: Machine learning classifier blocks in Scratch don't work
SCRATCH.Q3-A-1: Occassionally, the Scratch blocks for your machine learning model can lose the connection to the server. When this happens, they will stop returning results.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-2: You can check whether this has happened using the coloured status light in the "More Blocks" palette.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-3: If the status light next to your machine learning Scratch blocks is red, that normally means something is wrong. It might be a temporary problem. Try saving your project (using 'File' -> 'Save Project'), then refresh the browser page. If the status light goes green after the page reloads, you can load your project (using 'File' -> 'Load Project') to pick up where you left off.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-4: If the status light is still red after reloading the page, then there is probably something wrong with the machine learning model. Try going to the "Learn & Test" page for the project, which is where any error messages about your model can be found.
SCRATCH.Q3-A-5: If the status light next to your machine learning Scratch blocks is green, then the blocks should be working. If you're not getting the responses you expect from them, try going to the "Learn & Test" page and checking what results your model returns.
SCRATCH.Q4: Can it be used on an iPad?
SCRATCH.Q4-A-1: Machine Learning for Kids uses Scratch 2. Scratch needs Adobe Flash to work, so you need to be using an operating system and a web browser that can work with Flash (so that means no iPads for now, sorry).
SCRATCH.Q4-A-2: Scratch 3 is under development, and will remove the need for Adobe Flash. Once this is released, I hope that this will allow projects to be worked on from tablets like iPads. I'm not sure when this will be, though.
